author: Chippopotanuse
body:
One reason is that they aren’t static indexes. They are dynamic survivor bias indexes. What does that mean? 

It means they replace losers with winners. Go look at the Dow or S&P components from 1980 and see how the castoffs have fared. 

For the Dow, changes used to be VERY rare. From 1959-1976 there were ZERO changes. 

Now? It changes its components several times
a year. 

If it didn’t keep doing this, it wouldn’t “perform”
Nearly as well.

Look at how shitty GE has done over the past three years. They used to be THE corporate bellwether of the US economy. But GE’s plunge didn’t hurt the Dow at all. It was removed as a component in the middle of 2018. 

In March of 2015 the Dow added Apple to replace AT&T (once so big and fearful it had to be busted up by regulators, but is now a dogshit dividend stock). That one change alone did wonders for the Dow average. 

In Sept 2013, Nike, Goldman Sachs, and Visa replaced such dogs as Hewlett-Packard and Alcoa.

In 2009, Cisco Systems replaced GM.

Anyways, you get the point. The Dow and S&P, by definition, will always go up over time. They will simply drop dog sticks with no future and replace them with up and coming stalwarts. 

I’ve often looked, but have never found, a report that would show how the Dow and S&P would have performed if they didn’t modify their components and always stack the decks. 

TLDR: the Dow and S&P change the component stocks to always contain far more winners than losers. They will rise over time. They don’t reflect the more broad stock market as a whole, nor do they reflect how the average American family is doing economically. They just reflect a basket of “winning” stocks.

author: kneeil
body:
I would be careful about TSLA as a long-term play right now for 3 reasons:

1) it’s fairly unclear if Tesla will be able to retain their lead in EV. Many other automakers are entering EV. For instance, Toyota claims to have game-changing solid-state battery tech in the works. If this is true, then Toyota could potentially be the leader in EV (especially if you combine game-changing tech with their already-stellar reputation and market share). Or maybe some other car company. Who knows?
2) Tesla is currently very expensive. At a valuation of 600B, Tesla’s current price tag is on par with the largest, most successful, and highest-profit companies in the world. To buy now means you expect them long-term to continue going up on top of this already-massive valuation. Possible, but definitely risky (especially for a company that is very new, has relatively low profits, and isn’t very diversified).
3) currently, tesla’s valuation relies a lot on expectation of future earnings (nothing wrong with that; I like this style of investing). If the overall market takes a significant downturn before tesla can become very profitable, then their stock price will probably plummet (once the stock price goes down, people/institutions on margin need to sell, causing the price to go even lower, causing a cycle the way down; speculative stocks tend to get hit worst when this happens). Could be similar to Cisco circa 2000. Note that if this does happen, this might actually be a good time to buy shares for cheap if you do still believe in the long-term for tesla

These are just my thoughts. Not financial advice. I personally own put options on tesla (but also own shares of tesla in an account that someone else manages for me)

author: Safe_Blueberry
body:
I'm presuming you're American.

A lot of Canadian energy-related stocks are inexpensive, like CNQ, PBA, ENB, and TRP. The only thing that I want to point out is that there is a 15% dividend withholding tax if these stocks are not held in a retirement account.

There are a lot of good and inexpensive UK stocks, like LGGNY, BTI, RDS.B, and BBL. The only things that I want to point out is that British stocks tend to pay biannually, not quarterly, and there is no dividend withholding tax.

Other places without a dividend withholding tax include Hong Kong and Singapore. These two companies pay biannually and have caught my eye - SUHJY and UOVEY.

Inexpensive American dividend stocks include BEN, PFE, MO, WBA, VZ, and CSCO.

If you're interested in more American dividend stocks, I recommend looking at VYM's holdings. VYM is Vanguard's High Dividend Yield ETF.

author: EitherToe
body:
We are all in here for money, not for political garbage on what's right or wrong. Ignore the Reddit stupidity of "HurRrH Durrrrr, cHIna BAd" therefore stock go down. We see JP Morgan pull "I did not take a bribe" but here we are betting on them or some other unethical company. Didi even has Goldman Sachs, Apple and Uber buy-in/management/oversight. Alibaba has big names like Charlie Munger buying stock, most people wouldn't bet against these people/companies.

Big tech USA is never going to win in Asia, this makes no sense. People here who think the Chinese government is going to let AWS or Microsoft run its software have done no research. A market of 1.4 billion, expecting to reach a greater GDP in 5 or so years is going to open its legs for the US? Let that sink in for a moment, the richest people in the US are owners of large US companies and supported by the US government. Is China dumb enough to let Amazon in and give them a free business that can't be controlled? Huawei failed outside of China but it's going to be building Chinese IoT infrastructure just like Cisco, Salesforce, AWS etc. 

China already has its big tech equivalent, some of them turning volumes higher than their US counterparts. I won't push people to either side, just present some arguments. You bet on what you think will actually make you money given your risk tolerance.

Real estate investments include a four-story office building at 45 Belden St. in the Financial District, office buildings on Battery and Sansome streets near the Embarcadero, a building housing a Walgreens drugstore near Ocean Beach and other commercial property in San Anselmo.
Other investments include a St. Helena vineyard worth between $5 million and $25 million, a $1 million-plus townhome in Norden (Nevada County), and minority interests in the Auberge du Soleil resort hotel in Rutherford, the CordeValle Golf Club in San Martin, and the Piatti Italian restaurant chain."

Look at the date of that article 2007.

author: FinndBors
body:
> This ain’t like 2000

In a ton of valuation metrics they are worse than any other time in history other than 2000. And when people think of 2000, they think of pets.com being ridiculous. Those shit companies were not in any index and pets.com was 300-400 million market cap at its peak (which it held for a very short time). You can equate pets.com to companies like NKLA which make gravity powered trucks. NKLA was ~ 30B market cap at its peak -- and it's still worth 5B+. Pets.com actually had a business / revenue, tons of SPACs are little more than post series A companies, all of them worth well over a billion.

The "real" megacap tech companies of 2000 were hewlett packard, microsoft, ibm, csco, intel, sun, compaq, etc. Their P/E ratios are much closer to the FAANGs of today. And most of the peak P/E ratios happened after a series of bad earnings.

The only thing that is legitimately different now than before is low interest rates. Which is why inflation / fed reaction is a genuine serious fear.

author: LambdaLambo
body:
> Those shit companies were not in any index and pets.com was 300-400 million market cap at its peak (which it held for a very short time). You can equate pets.com to companies like NKLA which make gravity powered trucks. NKLA was ~ 30B market cap at its peak -- and it's still worth 5B+

That kinda helps my point though. NKLA tanked but it has no correlation to the overall stock market, and the whole stock market went up in fact. Same with the entire SPAC bubble. Yes it was a bubble, but it popped and the market moved on its way without missing a beat. 

> The "real" megacap tech companies of 2000 were hewlett packard, microsoft, ibm, csco, intel, sun, compaq, etc. Their P/E ratios are much closer to the FAANGs of today. And most of the peak P/E ratios happened after a series of bad earnings.

Even then the PE ratios are not the same. MSFT in it's peak in 1999 had a PE ratio of ~82, it now has a PE ratio of ~35. 

I'm not gonna say that *every* company today is fine. Many are not (including NKLA). But the 2000 was endemic throughout the market (i.e. say "internet" and stock 10x'd at ipo). Today the market is much more varied and plenty of companies trading at high multiples do so because they're growth is very real.

Sorta unrelated but I personally believe tech got an insane boost from covid which is/will be driving huge digitalization efforts and  accelerate growth for many saas/cloud centric companies.

I had friends who became paper multi-millionaires from a fukkin greetingcard.com company…then…poof…lost it all.

Multiply the above by a few thousand totally shady tech IPOs.

From Wiki…was totally mental…

Between 1995 and its peak in March 2000, the Nasdaq Composite stock market index rose 400%, only to fall 78% from its peak by October 2002, giving up all its gains during the bubble. During the crash, many online shopping companies, such as Pets.com, Webvan, and Boo.com, as well as several communication companies, such as Worldcom, NorthPoint Communications, and Global Crossing, failed and shut down.

Some companies, such as Cisco, whose stock declined by 86%, Amazon.com, and Qualcomm, lost a large portion of their market capitalization but survived.

author: DarthTrader357
body:
So what happened to you is called "getting stopped out" and it's a dumb risk that you never have to expose yourself to. I had fun in my last post but I'll explain more about what you ***probably should do.***

1. Buy 100 shares @ reasonable stock and price. If you like Amazon, CSCO may be reasonable alternative though it's in the 50s price range. Tech sector - strong - good dividend. Yatta yatta.
2. Sell a covered call @ strike price  you're willing to sell. Ideally put it in the expected move range. Delta = About 30. Or if you think the stock will go down (hence you want to sell out of it), sell a call at a strike somewhere in the money.
3. use the covered call to buy a put.
4. Using JPM as an example: Sell a covered call at $150 strike for $275 and buy a put for $117 dollars. You get paid $158 dollars to lock in a price between now and $149.
5. If the price is going to drop below $149 you simply buy back the covered call (Buy to Close) which will now be cheaper or if it falls out of the money you don't even need to worry about it, it expires worthless.
6. Exercise the put and sell your shares for $149, a price close to the top you wanted to sell out at anyway.

Voilla - a collar, in a nutshell.

You literally got paid to **EXIT** a stock when **YOU** wanted to.

author: EitherToe
body:
Tech is a dangerous area to invest in. I find these discussions really hit or miss and should come with a big warning. Tech like medical fields have enormous issues imo, you got companies lending money at 1-2% to anyone out there which should be illegal and imo will be soon enough. Uber is basically something that skirts labour laws and wants to be a monopoly. Medical breakthroughs on news are mostly lies/held by red tape (which it should be). 

Yeah, you got Apple and such, but these companies actually proved their worth on the balance sheet. China will (at least I strongly believe) have a great tech industry, but if you knew what they were, you wouldn't be here, you would be in some big boys club getting told what they are and aren't. Tech is an industry where the government boosts you up (lets be honest, the US heavily backs people like Cisco or Microsoft) or you do something that is a real breakthrough. But for every success story, there is another 10 failures, even though on paper it worked, you got people like Msft bashing your door with lawyers.

author: FlameoHotman-_-
body:
This has to be an unpopular opinion...and for the record, I distrust the CCP as much as the next person, but these crackdowns may not be entirely bad. Let's look at some examples:

\- So in this case, Didi's operation got suspended because "Didi had illegally collected users' personal data."

\- Alibaba got fined because of monopolistic practices.

\- Ant Group's IPO got slashed because the CCP wanted to regulate Ant Group like an actual bank.

To be honest, these sound pretty reasonable to me. Facebook was in trouble for collecting data without content too. Remember the whole Cambridge Analytica scandal? But now everyone is hot for FB stocks.

Microsoft has been fined millions by the EU for monopolistic practices as well. But everyone loves Microsoft stocks nonetheless. 

And as to Ant Group, they are a massive financial service company that can offer customers credit. How come they don't get to be regulated like a bank? My point is that these actions make sense and good regulations is beneficial for investors too in the long run.

author: Pdicky69
body:
$NET is on a fundamental basis is over valued. They expect rev to be $500M+ this year but they trade at $33B. It’s been on of my biggest picked winners. 

Here is a quick breakdown of what the popular services they offer, highly scaleable and a HUGE TAM.

https://www.freelancer.com/articles/web-development/cloudflare

However I sold off at $75, $85 levels due to price action getting ahead of the fundamental business. I’ve exited about 50% of my position. I still have 200 shares because I believe, it could do some long term stuff well and be a $100B company. But I can’t allocate so much of my portfolio in this company vs a FB/AMZN/GOOG (where I get growth, balance sheet safety, and moat)

From here, if you want to get in on the action. You have to believe they do a few things…
1) surprise HEAVILY on revenue growth and forward guidance
2) grow more into their cyber security suite of tools beyond just basic stuff like their widely used DDOS prevention (a ton of websites use them for this) and firewall 
3) Content delivery network investment trend continues and profit margins aren’t competed away with bigger boys entering the game (ie GOOG, MSFT, AMZN)
4) website speeds overwhelmingly determine ranking on google and mobile searches

Cloudflare and Fastly are the two more popular services for websites and apps to use as they offer ease of use to speed up website access for users and support to prevent website downtime. Folks have frequently complimented on how easy cloudflare is to use.

author: RunningJay
body:
Let's take MSFT at 20%. Let's say you put $5000 in and you're now at $6000.  I always like to keep the capital invested and take only profit so I'd sell 4x MSFT, or if I was more confident only 3x @ \~$832.95.

Now technically you're not taking profits exactly, you're just taking cash off the table.

With AAPL, same theory, if you invested $1000, you're currently at $1500, so sell $500 worth to return to your original capital investement.

&#x200B;

Whatever you do with that $ better out-perform MSFT or AAPL, otherwise, just leave it there.

author: doggy_lovers
body:
Microsoft in the 1990s was the most valuable company in the world switching spots with GE, it is currently the only company that was in the top 10 list in 1990 and is currently still top 10 right now (at #2 spot behind apple). It was the #1 company by marketcap in 2019 and march 2020.

Moreover, It has never fallen out of the top 10 list for more than 20+ years even with failure of Ballmer, tech bubble crash, Nokia, etc. Now with the new ceo, I dont see it going out of the top 10 especially since it is so far ahead from #10 spot which is Alibaba at 600 billion market cap. (Microsoft is worth 2.1 trillion).

Back in the 1990s #1 spot had 200 billion valuation compared to 100 billion for #10 spot. So now the Top 5 companies are much more valuable compared to the bottom 5 of the list. Unlike the 1990s the top companies were not investing to the future and focus on short term profits.

Microsoft continues to invest in the future with the cloud technology, ai, vr/ar tech as well as is extremely diversified with equal 33% weight in 3 different classified segments.(the other trillion companies aren't as diversified). Finally, it is one of two companies (other being JNJ) with triple AAA credit rating, higher than the US government. It faces less regulatory risk than tech giants competitors allowing for easy acquisitions thanks to its stellar balance sheet.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization#2012

author: harrison_wintergreen
body:
ELI5: 

- Burry believes (as he wrote): "passive investing has removed price discovery from the equity markets". https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-04/michael-burry-explains-why-index-funds-are-like-subprime-cdos

- price discovery is the process of estimating a reasonable fair value for a stock. 

- because relatively few people are buying/selling stocks based on their fair value, prices for stocks are often being determined mainly by cash-flows. see Tesla or dogecoin for examples. Tesla sells under 1% all vehicles worldwide but is somehow worth *more than all the other carmakers combined* because lots of people were buying Tesla stock and not because of any financial status of Tesla. dogecoin started LITERALLY as a joke but somehow was more valuable than companies like Ford Motors only because a ton of cash flowed into Dogecoin. this is all sheer insanity by traditional stock valuation guidelines. asset bubbles are nothing new, but Burry believes it's being exacerbated by passive investing. 

- Burry believes this situation of prices being based on cash flows is similar to what happened in the housing bubble, when multi-zillion Collateralized Debt Obligations (CDOs) were being priced not by a reasonable estimate of their fair value but by cash-flows. 

- when flows reverse and lots of people want out of index funds, it will get ugly because so many stocks are linked/benchmarked to major stock indexes *including lower volume stocks*. consider VTI: the top holdings (Apple, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson) might have a billion shares in total and hundreds of millions of dollars trading each day. but the smallest company stocks might have only a few million shares and a few million dollars trading each day. if too many people want to sell all at the same time, it will drive prices down sharply because these stocks are so often sold as a bundle/unit. as Burry puts it: "The theater keeps getting more crowded, but the exit door is the same as it always was"

>since the guy predicted 2007-2008 crash.

he also predicted the dot-com bubble.

author: justsomescrub
body:
Not so much diversifying as just straight up killing it. Operating income rose 189% from 2019 to 2020 with eps up 604%. Q1 2021 operating income is up 266% and eps is up 232% from Q1 2020 and it isn't *just* higher margins; Total revenue in 2020 was up 45% from 2019 and Q1 2021 total rev Is up 92% compared to Q1 2020. Oh and the XLNX acquisition or whatever pending china approval.

  
AND there are some tasty insider whispers IF TRUE insinuating next gen GPU performance above and beyond what they expect from Nvidia. FULL STOP. Not at bargain price points, or for certain niche applications just straight up expecting to have the best GPUs on the market next gen. Nvidia having something spicy up their sleeve non-withstanding; you never know with Nvidia.   

  Add in plans to buy back 4 billion worth of shares over the next 4(?) Years with cash on hand and plans for 3nm production by 2024 and everything I hear about AMD makes me think up up up. They have new deals with Samsung for their phones and google/amazon for servers, to add to the pile of deals like making chips for Sony and Microsoft consoles. The future looks bright.

I put 90% of my account in AMD last month when they were hovering around 80$ without a single worry and I haven't unwound my position yet. Hoping for 2021 guidance to be adjusted from 50% to 75% growth to set this thing off again. Or merger approval, whatever comes first.

author: zxc123zxc123
body:
Hi. I'm from the Intel side! I think AMD side shouldn't worry too much about INTC. It's a big old ship that's getting bombarded from all sides. The fact that it's a big ship means it's changes will take time. I'm giving Gelsinger a chance to right the ship, but it will take a long while to undo BSwan's bad moves, get the right people, develop the chips, and catch up to AMD. 

A plus side for everyone is that the semi-space is a growing area with electronification, digitization, and "5G-cloudification" of everything along with the increasing importance of AI & tech in business and government. Semis are so important in fact, that at this point US Gov should really be looking at INTC/NVD/TI more like they did Ford/GM 100 years ago: as a strategic industrial/military resource. 

Real threat to AMD isn't INTC. INTC was the big market share holder in the past and isn't likely gaining any ground any time soon. What AMD and all the trad chip manufacturers should fear is FAAAM & BAT. Apple has started designing it's own chips. They aren't going back to using outsourced chips. If history says anything it's that Apple will continue to cut others out as they continue to in-house their chips for their entire lineup while improving their chips just like how they kept improving their computers, just like how the iphone kept improving until NOK/MOT were beat, just like how a good chunk of the watch market is Apple watches, just like how Ipads have taken away from of the laptop space, just like how Apple TV keeps chipping away at cable, just like how the app store and Apple's eco system keeps growing, etcetcetc. There is nothing AMD/NVD/INTC can do to stop Apple. And Apple is just the first. MSFT also doing the same. Google, Facebook, and Amazon might follow suit. China's Tencent and Alibaba will likely copy what the US companies do as soon as Pooh Bear gets done man handling them.

author: left_turn_signal
body:
"The bulk of the Pelosis' money comes from investments in stocks and real estate. Operating through Financial Leasing Services, his San Francisco investment firm, Paul Pelosi owns stock in companies including Microsoft, AT&T, Cisco Systems, Disney, Johnson & Johnson and a variety of tech stocks.
Real estate investments include a four-story office building at 45 Belden St. in the Financial District, office buildings on Battery and Sansome streets near the Embarcadero, a building housing a Walgreens drugstore near Ocean Beach and other commercial property in San Anselmo.
Other investments include a St. Helena vineyard worth between $5 million and $25 million, a $1 million-plus townhome in Norden (Nevada County), and minority interests in the Auberge du Soleil resort hotel in Rutherford, the CordeValle Golf Club in San Martin, and the Piatti Italian restaurant chain."

Look at the date of that article 2007. 

(https://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/Pelosi-s-husband-prefers-a-low-profile-2660253.php)

author: YourInnate
body:
It's a matter of perspective and big picture stuff. If you bough a SPY leap the day before the market crashed last year from covid, and bought 100 shares the day before the crash in covid, the LEAP would be worth more today.

2-5% a month seems super low, but options are a grind. When in doubt, zoom out. 2-5% a month is 25-60% a year. Consider the indexes historically return 10%, doubling that on your bad years and quintupling it on your good years seems like a good trade.

Another note, this past year has been a historic bull run/recovery for most of the stock market. You can't compare throwing money into microsoft or google and watching it appreciate vs selling options on the same underlying. Likewise, if you had been selling RIOT/MARA puts the first 4 months of the year, you could've been making 10% a week. 

Everything in the market is perspective. If you think 2-5% a month is too slow/boring... You might consider roulette.

author: BigBrianBrand
body:
Alibaba is the best Buy and Hold example that fits your question. 

It has perceived government regulation risk. Similar to what Facebook has been through these last 3 years. As long as the financials continue to grow, the stock will eventually skyrocket. 

Etsy, VRTX, nVidia, Apple, Facebook, Amazon, Google, Tesla, and Microsoft are also moderate risk picks in terms of their current price
